et: Middle English {it}apostel, apostle, postel,{/it} in part going back to Old English {it}apostol,{/it} in part borrowed from Anglo-French {it}apostle, apostoile, appostre,{/it} both borrowed from Late Latin {it}apostolus{/it} "ambassador, Apostle (of the New Testament)," borrowed from Greek {it}apóstolos{/it} "messenger, envoy, (Septuagint) messenger from God, (New Testament) Apostle," noun derivative of {it}apostéllein{/it} "to send off or away, dispatch," from {it}apo-{/it} {et_link|apo-|apo-} + {it}stéllein{/it} "to set in order, equip, prepare for a journey, send," going back to Indo-European {it}*stel-{/it} "put up, prepare," whence also Old Church Slavic po{it}steljǫ,{/it} po{it}stĭlati{/it} "to spread out," Albanian {it}shtiell{/it} "wind up, reel up, collect" (from {it}*stel-n-{/it}) and perhaps Old Prussian {it}stallīt{/it} "to stand," Armenian {it}stełcanem,{/it} (aorist) {it}stełci{/it} "prepare, create" (with {it}-c-{/it} of uncertain origin)

Along with Attic-Ionic {it}stéllein,{/it} Greek forms in Lesbian dialect and forms attested by the grammarian Hesychius that appear to be Aeolic show a variant {it}spel-/spol-.{/it} This has led to the conjecture of a distinct root {it}*sk{sup}w{/sup}el-{/it} "set in order" alongside {it}*stel-{/it} "send"; however, the evidence for {it}*sk{sup}w{/sup}el-{/it} outside Greek is exiguous. Germanic {it}*stal(l)jan-{/it} "to fix, set, place" (whence Old English {it}stellan,{/it} Old Saxon {it}stellian,{/it} Old High German {it}stellen{/it}) could be an outcome of {it}*stel-,{/it} though it is usually taken as denominal from {it}*stalla-{/it} "stand, stall, stable" (see {et_link|stall:1|stall:1}).
